title: Boris Karlov (bulgarian gypsy-accordeon) 1924-1964 - 2CDs
description:
Boris Karlov (1924-1964)

Legend of the Bulgarian Accordion

This 2-CD set features 40 exciting folk melodies played by the legendary Bulgarian accordionist and compiled by Yves Moreau from the archives of the Bulgarian National Radio, Balkanton records and rare old 78's. 

Boris Karlov is credited for being the first to develop a distinct technique and style for playing Bulgarian folk music on the accordion. This compilation presents the Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â«classicsÃƒâ€šÃ‚Â» of Karlov's repertoire in chronological order. Boris Karlov was an usurpassed accordion player with an exquisite and particular beautiful tone, full of emotionality. He was a folk musician with an iron sense of rhythm and brilliant technique who played Bulgarian folk melodies with an infectious musical sensitivity. Some of his tunes have become standard favorites among North American Balkan music and dance adepts: Bavno Horo, Gjusevska Rachenitsa, Daichovo Horo, Gankino Horo, Elenino Horo, etc.

Wiki:
"Boris Karlov (11 August, 1924ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Å“14 December, 1964) was a Bulgarian accordionist. He was born in Sofia into a family with a gypsy background. His father was the conductor of an orchestra that was often heard on radio Sofia.

At an early age Boris was already passionate about folk music, played first on the ocarina and later on the tambura in his father's orchestra. Here he acquired a feeling for the harmonic structure of Bulgarian music. At twelve years of age Karlov began to play the accordion, beginning with a simple 48-base Hohner instrument, and progressing to a 120-base. Eventually he had a custom Italian Scandalli accordion made for him.

In the years 1950ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Å“1960, Karlov was in demand not only in Bulgaria, but also in Yugoslavia and Austria. He had a busy concert schedule and favourable reviews. Karlov developed a style of playing which was new on the accordion. Based on generally short, simple, but fast musical phrases, frequently in the irregular rhythms that were originally played on traditional Bulgarian instruments such as the gaida (bagpipe) and kaval (end-blown flute), he innovated a rondo form where the special character of Bulgarian music nevertheless remained.

He died, still on tour, in Kraljevo, of a kidney infection"
